**Splint mail** is a type of [body armor](/wiki/Body_armor "Body armor") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Origin](#Origin)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [6.3 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [6.4 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

All [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai") start the game with +0 non-cursed splint mail[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) - their starting splint mail will be [rustproof](/wiki/Rustproof "Rustproof"), along with any splint mail generated on the same floor due to the method employed in the code, and all splint mail generated on the [Samurai quest](/wiki/Samurai_quest "Samurai quest") will also be rustproof.[\[2\]](#cite_note-lacquer-2)

In addition to random generation, general [stores](/wiki/Store "Store"), used armor dealerships and antique weapon outlets can sell splint mail.

[Mercenaries](/wiki/Mercenaries "Mercenaries") with a target [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") of 2 or better (e.g., [Yendorian Army](/wiki/Yendorian_Army "Yendorian Army") [sergeants](/wiki/Sergeant "Sergeant")) that do not receive [plate mail](/wiki/Plate_mail "Plate mail") or [crystal plate mail](/wiki/Crystal_plate_mail "Crystal plate mail") have an effective 8⁄15 chance of [generating with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") splint mail.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

[Player monster](/wiki/Player_monster "Player monster") [barbarians](/wiki/Barbarian_\(player_monster\) "Barbarian (player monster)"), [knights](/wiki/Knight_\(player_monster\) "Knight (player monster)"), [priests](/wiki/Priest_\(player_monster\) "Priest (player monster)"), and [valkyries](/wiki/Valkyrie_\(player_monster\) "Valkyrie (player monster)") have an effective 1⁄10 chance of forcing splint mail in place of their initial body armor.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

As part of [commit 20cbadcf](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/20cbadcf85544cf9d0c3f4e4200b2800bab49c8e) - which strengthens [quest leaders](/wiki/Quest_leader "Quest leader") and makes it so that killing them no longer makes the game [unwinnable](/wiki/Unwinnable "Unwinnable") - the [Samurai quest](/wiki/Samurai_quest "Samurai quest") leader [Lord Sato](/wiki/Lord_Sato "Lord Sato") always generates with +5 splint mail.

## Description

While worn, splint mail confers 6 base [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") and [MC1](/wiki/MC1 "MC1").

## Strategy

Splint mail provides a significant AC bonus, but is the second-heaviest type of armor at 400 [aum](/wiki/Aum "Aum") after the various forms of [plate mail](/wiki/Plate_mail "Plate mail"), which weighs 50 units more. Samurai will be able to wear their starting splint mail for some time with their high [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") and [constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution"), but should look for upgrades such as [banded mail](/wiki/Banded_mail "Banded mail"), or an [elven](/wiki/Elven_mithril-coat "Elven mithril-coat") or [dwarvish mithril-coat](/wiki/Dwarvish_mithril-coat "Dwarvish mithril-coat"), as soon as possible.

## History

Splint mail first appears in Hack 1.21 and Hack for PDP-11, which are based on [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"), and is included in the initial list of armor for [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Splint armour](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Splint_armour "wikipedia:Splint armour")***

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Tatami-dō](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tatami-d%C5%8D "wikipedia:Tatami-dō")***

Splint armour (also splinted armour, splint armor, or splinted armor) is a form of historic armor composed of strips of metal "splints" attached to a cloth or leather backing or 'foundation'. It was most commonly used in armor such as greaves or vambraces that covers the limbs: the splints are arranged length-wise and pierced for riveting or sewing to the foundation. While a few complete suits of armour have been found made from splints of wood, leather, or bone, the Victorian neologism of "splinted mail" usually refers to the limb armor of crusader knights from the era: depictions of this type pair it with mail, scale armour, a coat of plates, or other plate harness.

The "splinted mail" of 14th century Europe was one of many forms of [transitional armour](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/transitional_armour "wikipedia:transitional armour") that improved on simple mail shirts, in this case by adding limb protection via methods such as the aforementioned greaves alongside more thorough coverage for the thigh and upper arm. Knights in effigy are depicted with further leg protection that fully covers the feet as well and may also represent the presence of rivets on brigandines or padded armour underneath splints. Splint mail usually appears in media that draws from the era, including "standard" fantasy such as *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*.

The feudal era of Japan likewise featured various forms of *tatami gusoku*, a type of lightweight portable folding Japanese armour worn by the samurai class and their foot soldiers, and includes a jacket along with a helmet, hood or similar type of head protection alongside the usual components of a full suit of armor. Tatami armour was designed to be convenient for transportation, and were manufactured inexpensively for light infantry; lower-class samurai wore simpler tatami, where higher-class samurai wore more elaborate tatami. The rustproof splint mail used for Samurai in *NetHack* most likely represents tatami made of *karuta*, small lacquered square or rectangular plates of iron (or sometimes leather) usually connected together by chainmail and sewn to a cloth backing - a comment in the source code supports this, indicating that it represents the historical use of lacquer to protect Japanese armor in a wet climate.[\[2\]](#cite_note-lacquer-2)

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), [gnoll warriors](/wiki/Gnoll_warrior "Gnoll warrior") have an effective 19⁄60 chance of generating with splint mail.[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), splint mail confers 3 AC, 3 [DR](/wiki/DR "DR") and MC1 while worn, and its weight is reduced to 200 aum.

[Incantifier](/wiki/Incantifier "Incantifier") Samurai have their starting splint mail replaced with a [robe](/wiki/Robe "Robe").

[Lord Sato](/wiki/Lord_Sato "Lord Sato") always generates with blessed +4 splint mail.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), the weight of splint mail is reduced to 300 aum.

[Giant](/wiki/Giant_\(starting_race\) "Giant (starting race)") Samurai start the game with [large splint mail](/wiki/Large_splint_mail "Large splint mail") in place of the standard splint, and [tortle](/wiki/Tortle_\(starting_race\) "Tortle (starting race)") Samurai receive their race's standard [toque](/wiki/Toque "Toque") in lieu of splint mail.

Lord Sato always generates with +4 splint mail.

Splint mail can be created at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") by combining [chain mail](/wiki/Chain_mail "Chain mail") and [scale mail](/wiki/Scale_mail "Scale mail"). Splint mail can also be combined with chain mail to forget [plate mail](/wiki/Plate_mail "Plate mail").

All of the above information also applies to [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM").

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), in addition to SLASH'EM details, incantifier Samurai start with a [robe](/wiki/Robe_\(SLASH%27EM\) "Robe (SLASH'EM)") in place of splint mail as in dNetHack.
